author: Wing
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2017
review_content: I love this drill. It has saved me so much time on my home improvement projects (which basically means putting furniture together and drilling holes in the walls to mount things). The battery is great and honestly, I can't say how long it lasts because it has never run out while I've been using it. Granted, I only use it for about an hour at most and then I stick the battery back on the charger, but it seems to hold a charge very well too since there have been times when I haven't charged it for about a month, put the battery in the drill, and it still worked as if the battery was full.The drill bits that come with it are standard sizes although I wish the sockets came in more sizes. They are too small for most things I want to use them for. Other than that, this drill is perfect.

As shown in the picture, the drill gets rusty after only a couple months.
title: Can't hold the drill head straight. Drill head gets rusty.

author: anushree
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2020
review_content: I purchased this item on Nov, 2018 and have never used it outside my apartment. My issue here is with the quality and durability of drill bits provided as accessories with the item of purchase. As mentioned in product details, I have used it on wood and metal surface drilling. The 3/16 inch drill bit broke off while drilling a wood surface. The tip of 5/16 inch drill bit broke off while drilling a metal surface. Additionally, I drilled on a ceramic surface and that's when the 5/32 inch drill bit broke off. I do understand that ceramic surface wasn't present in product details, but considered it would since the drill works with metals. These incidents didn't happen during first use, but took place within 6-8 months after my purchase as I did use them for multiple jobs at home. Also, the drilling wasn't on bare surface, as I did make a dent with nail before pointing each drill on surface. To ensure this still wasn't because of my naive drilling skills, I purchased a second drill bit set from DeWalt a little less than year ago and used it for the same incomplete tasks at home. However, I don't see a repeat of broken drill bit incidents here. Hence, my review comes at roundabout 1.5 years post my purchase. It's fair to expect that the drill bits coming as accessories with this item should have run longer. On checking the Black & Decker 2-year limited warranty for this item, it appears that accessories aren't part of that limited warranty. As a result, it wasn't a wrong decision purchasing a separate drill bit set. However, an option should be made available to either include accessories (like drill bit) in the limited warranty or not providing them with the item at first place. In that way, customers can purchase this item for a price minus that of accessories and use drill bits of their choice that run longer. But the question about quality of the drill bits offered as accessories on this item still continues to be open for me. As proof, I have provided pictures of the affected drill bits with this review.
title: Drill bit accessories ruined within first year of purchase

author: ssegal
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2020
review_content: My Black&Decker 20V Drill caught on fire after 6 days of use. I used it for less than 30 min a day for the first five days, and after charging the battery overnight, I tried to use the drill and it did not work (just beeped). After about 4 seconds, significant amounts of smoke started pouring out of the motor, melting the plastic. Please be careful with this. Please be careful if you purchase this product, it may catch on fire.
title: SAFETY: This is likely a knock-off - mine caught on fire after six days.

I'm looking for the manufacturer/warranty paperwork to see what I need to do to get this resolved.

author: Yellie

author: S. L. S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2018
review_content: This drill (B&D LD120VA) is perfect for light jobs but nothing heavy duty. This drill only has one speed, so if you are doing anything that needs some power, you'll need to upgrade. (it won't drill or screw into anything with resistance)This drill is incredibly light weight and the price is right considering it comes with battery, charger and some basic accessories. (Great for someone who doesn't have a lot of strength)UPDATE: Now that I have had this a week and the Black & Decker BDCDD220C 20V MAX Lithium 2-Speed Drill/Driver - I am returning both! Do not waste your money on either one of these drills.If you are somehow forced into buying a B&D Drill, buy the 20V MAX 2 speed - but know that it is for simple house jobs only. Because the chuck will not hold a drill bit/driver if there is any resistance and it does not have a break stop (if you let go of the trigger, it will continue to spin) which can be dangerous.
title: Only has power for SUPER light duty jobs only.

author: Fruit Batwoman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2019
review_content: I bought this as my first power drill. I had in mind to hang my new 49” TV and assemble a bookcase I bought from Amazon. I saw a review on here that told people not to listen to the reviews of amateurs, but since this drill seems to be marketed to amateurs, I think our opinions do count. I wasn’t expecting to drill holes in my sidewalk or build a house with this sucker—I just wanted a basic handyman’s drill.Full disclosure: I did not charge the drill before first use, so I may not have had full power when attempting to hang my TV. That said, the drill seemed to have trouble driving the included bit into the wall and the wooden stud behind it. Then in reverse, the drill did not seem to have enough torque, even on the maximum setting, to pull the bit out of the wall. The bit kept coming out of the chuck. So my television remains un-hung.The next task I put this drill to (after a full charge) was to screw together the panels of a new bookcase. Keep in mind that the holes were already partially pre-drilled by the bookcase manufacturer, so it should’ve been a piece of cake. Well, it wasn’t terribly difficult to drive the screws in, but the bit kept coming away from the screws, which caused a few little marks on my new bookcase. By the time the screws were installed properly, many of the heads were partially stripped, and what’s worse, there were little metal shavings deposited on the bookcase. I’ve used other people’s power drills before and never encountered this issue. As I was assembling the bookcase next to one of my cats’ dishes, I had to toss the food and wash the bowl out just in case some metal shavings had fallen in—better safe than sorry.I honestly can’t recommend this as either a basic drill or as an electric screwdriver. I’m returning this and will be saving my money up for a Milwaukee or even Ryobi at the hardware store.
title: Inadequate Even as a Basic Tool

author: Sierra Elise
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2017
review_content: I was very surprised when this drill arrived. Though it is a 20V Drill, it is about half the size of any other drill I have ever owned - some that are even less powerful than this one claimed to be. I will be honest, I was rather skeptical of how well it would work just by its size. I guess size isn't everything though. After using it a few times, I started to get a feel for it and I was willing to use it for more heavy duty projects. I have found that this small drill, which is an amazing size to keep in a compact carrying case, is very powerful, while also remaining pretty quiet. The chuck works very smoothly as well, no issues holding the bits, breaking, sticking, or falling out. The size and weight make it VERY easy to use and that is something I am thankful for. In the past, I have stayed away from my husband's tools because of the size and power, but this is a drill for everyone. I am not 100% on giving this drill 5/5 just yet, but after a few more major home improvement projects I will let you know, our next one will be putting it through the ultimate test.
title: Lightweight, compact, quiet, small but powerful!

author: Jeremiah
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2019
review_content: I can't say enough complimentary things about this drill!  I purchased it when I began a long-term home renovation project two years ago and have used it extensively since then.  To date, it has been used to install numerous fixtures (lights, fans, etc.), drill and assemble custom built shelves, fasten over 2,000 square feet of drywall, fasten cement board for tile floors and backer board for custom showers, and many other tasks.A few specific notes:1.  The battery life is great; however, you may notice a bit of a battery drain when performing heavy duty tasks like driving self-tapping screws into backer board (which is extremely dense, so the drill has to work very hard to complete this task).  Even when performing this task, I did not find myself running out of battery power in the middle of tasks.  I typically charge the battery every few days, but I found myself needing to charge the battery on a nightly or semi-nightly basis (which is still not bad at all) when taxing the drill heavily.  I have never needed to purchase a second battery because one charge easily lasts through a full day of consistent use.2.  This drill measures up very well against other cordless drills of the same class.  When people have helped me to hang drywall and backer board, their drills have not been able to accomplish the tasks as easily as this one.  I have handed my drill to other people on numerous occasions so that they could drive screws the rest of the way after their cordless drills could not complete the task.3.  There are some natural limitations with this drill, but that is to be expected with a cordless drill.  For example, I can use this drill with large hole saw bits; however, it is significantly faster to use my 6 amp corded drill for this work.  Similarly, when using a spade bit to drill through multiple 2x4 headers, it is much faster to use a more powerful drill.  This drill can do the job, but it will take more time since it is simply not the right tool for that particular job.Summary:  If this drill is used for the right tasks and is treated well, it will perform better than many drills that occupy higher price ranges and it will also last for a very long time.  I have put this drill through its paces many times over in the last two years and it has never disappointed me.
title: The right tool for the right job(s)

author: Ian T. Cassinos
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2019
review_content: I was super excited to get this drill to tackle a few projects. I wanted a mikita or dewault but settled for this mostly because of the price and the great reviews. I know for the price point I shouldn't expect a Lamborghini on a Kia budget, but I was thinking with all the rave reviews it would be ok. The drill works...ok. Into soft wood, screws go good. Drywall? anything harder? Click Click Click Click Click. No power. I got halfway into studs on a full charge and couldnt sink the screws into the drywall. They went in, but didn't sink down. I'm going to keep it as it is lightweight and should handle some light duty work, but I'm still looking at a bigger drill for future use.
title: So-So for Light Duty but weak

author: Marsellus Wallace
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2019
review_content: Okay, this drill is well worth the acclamation it currently has. I bought it with the drillbit set for about $75. I needed to drill holes through a metal beam behind my car's bumper to screw on mounts for musical horns. At first, this little drill started to sweat. I was thinking buying this was a bad idea... but... I didn't give up. So first off, I made sure the battery was fully charged... which by the way, takes a LONG time to do, upwards of 3-4hrs. Well, it got fully charged, and boom, huge difference.Also, you have to make sure you're using the right drill bit... there's three types: The multi-purpose drill (which is what you should use for metal), the masonry bit, and the carpenter's bit (forgot the name). I switched to the appropriate drillbit, and... in a big facepalm moment, realized I had the drill spinning in the UNSCREW direction. Be careful, since it's really easy to accidentally press down the button that switches the spin to reverse . So, now, with:1. Full battery2. Appropriate drill bit3. Making sure the spin is set to FORWARDI was able to drill a hole through 1/6" cast iron in less than a minute. And yes, like others have mentioned, this is not a heavy duty drill, but keep in mind heavy duty drills run at the very least $150, while this one was half the price with drillbits included. In conclusion, this is a purchase I certainly do not regret making. Hooray!
title: Yes! It drills metal.

author: Andarton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2020
review_content: I had a tiny cordless drill from Ikea and it was working fine for my needs. But then one day I had to repair a roof and ended up borrowing a neighbor's cordless drill. After that, the Ikea drill just didn't really feel like it was enough for the things I'd been using it for before (such as repairing fences). So I looked around for an affordable but heavier duty option.This was a bit of an impulse purchase. The reviews looked good and the price was right. So far I'm very pleased. Luckily there was a second, longer one and I just put that one directly into the drill instead of using the screwdriver adapter and it worked great.I would say that this is a good drill for the price!

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2019
review_content: Ok, I bought this on a deal-of-the-day or some special like that.  I thought it seemed like a deal even if it didn't really hold up over time. Then I decided to use it to install a metal roof.  I was driving 3.5 inch screws through 2x4s into rafters.  Plenty of torque to drive the screws and battery held up longer than me.  Then I was screwing down the metal to the stringers and it just kept going.  I developed some respect for this thing.  Yes, it is not a dewalt, but it does pretty good for a fraction of the price.  This may not be commercial grade or even hardcore DIY, but it's way more than enough for a casual DIY'er in my opinion.  Oh, and the bits that come with it are junk, but overall I would probably buy this again if it was a daily-deal.

author: suchdisappoint
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2020
review_content: I bought this because I wanted to drill 2 holes into a wall stud that were too far away from an electrical outlet for me to use my plug in AC drill. Unfortunately, due to inaccuracies on this Amazon listing I bought this weak electric screwdriver by mistake instead of buying an actual drill made by dewalt.When trying to drill into a stud in the "drill" setting, it wobbled like crazy and no matter how firmly I tried to press straight into the wood, it would just go in an angle and would rather chew up the surrounding drywall than go through the wood. After 30 minutes of unsuccessfully trying to make the holes and having to patch the wall with wood filler, I gave up and got an extension cord. 2 minutes later, there were 2 perfectly straight holes made in the wall by the plug in drill. After screwing in two long screws into the 2 holes in the studs, I thought I would test this electric screwdriver to see whether it could unscrew them. Shockingly, they could not.Unfortunately I had to return. I hope they edit their Amazon listing to be more accurate so customers won't be misled. If they're reading this, this might help: please find and replace every instance of "drill" with "plastic toy electric non-functional screwdriver" as other customers may also be in my situation and could be misled. 3/5 stars.

author: JB

review_content: With that said, the cordless drill did the job. I bought it because I finally wanted handles on my kitchen cabinets.
